did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Records of the Province of St. John the Baptist Franciscans, 1868-1978 (bulk 1906-1965)

origination.label: Creator:
origination.corpname: Franciscans. Province of St. John the Baptist

did.abstract: The collection includes correspondence, financial records, official documents, reports, maps, articles, publications, photographs, postcards, and notes. The bulk of the collection is correspondence and records relating to the establishment and operation of missions and schools, primarily at St. Michaels. These document activity between Franciscan friars, the Navajo population, Catholic organizations, the U. S. Government, and the Land Commissioner of the Santa Fe Pacific Railroad Company. Included are materials on Navajo land allotments, education, language, social conditions, government and church relations, tourism, and origins of the Navajo Tribal Council.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

The user agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the Arizona Board of Regents for the University of Arizona, its officers, employees, and agents from and against all claims made by any person asserting that he or she is an owner of copyright.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Province of St. John the Baptist Franciscans records (AZ 500). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: In 1887, Franciscan friars established St. Michaels Mission in Apache County, Arizona. Its purpose was to bring Catholic doctrine and education to the Navajo Reservation in Arizona and New Mexico. St. Michaels Press was established in 1909, and still produces materials on Navajo and missionary topics.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into fourteen series:

list.item: Series I: St. Michaels Mission, 1898-1978
Series II: Other Southwest Missions, 1899-1975
Series III: Catholic Organizations, 1900-1976
Series IV: Land Records, 1868-1973
Series V: Province of St. John the Baptist, 1897-1976
Series VI: Franciscan Fathers, 1902-1975
Series VII: Catholic Church, 1895-1975
Series VIII: United States Government Offices and Indian Organizations, 1905-1971
Series IX: Indian Education, 1908-1972
Series X: Navaho Indians, 1899-1975
Series XI: Estates, Guardianships and Wills, 1929-1967
Series XII: Father Emanuel Trockur, 1924-1977
Series XIII: Robert L. Wilken's Anselm Weber, O. F. M.: Missionary to the Navaho , 1898-1921, Bruce Publishing Company, 1955, 1949-1973
Series XIV: Oversize Material, 1906-1973

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, financial records, official documents, reports, maps, articles, publications, photographs, postcards, and notes. The bulk of the collection is correspondence and records relating to the establishment and operation of missions and schools, primarily at St. Michaels. These document activity between Franciscan friars, the Navajo population, Catholic organizations, the U. S. Government, and the Land Commissioner of the Santa Fe Pacific Railroad Company. Included are materials on Navajo land allotments, education, language, social conditions, government and church relations, tourism, and origins of the Navajo Tribal Council.

Information in publications includes background material relating to the first Navajo dictionary; Kay Bennet's book, The Navajo Saga; Robert L. Wilken's book, Anselm Weber; and the periodical The Padre's Trail. Also present are extracts and complete examples of church publications on Navajo Indians and missionary work. Correspondents include Berard Haile, Leopold Ostermann, and Anselm Weber, other Franciscan Fathers, U.S. government officials, Catholic missionary organizations, Navajo individuals, and others. The papers of Emanuel Trockur include correspondence, writings, and his work with the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine. Photographs represent events, mission buildings, equipment and personnel.

scopecontent.p: "Die Franziskaner-Mission unter den Navajo-Indianern," published in Der Sendbote des Gottlichen Herzens Jesu. A series of monthly unsigned accounts of mission activity in the Southwest, 1899-1921, by Father Anselm Weber. Father Frederick Hartung filled in from July-November 1900. Father Egbert Fisher did several issues during 1912, 1913 and 1915.
